Of course, when I refer to queer-coding, I'm referring to the specific method of portraying LGBTQ characters that became popular in cinema after the implementation of the Hays Code in 1934.  Because any type of quote-unquote sex perversion was prohibited from films of the time, filmmakers began writing characters that were heavily implied to be LGBTQ through stereotypical behavior, but not through explicit statements.  This played a role in not only emboldening queer stereotypes, but ingraining them into the medium of film.
